Avatar Guide

Problem

In AR‚Äëenhanced museum settings, guests may overlook salient points of interest despite the presence of a preconfigured route. Traditional planar indicators‚Äîsuch as arrows or floor decals‚Äîoffer limited guidance for regulating walking pace and preserving orientation, particularly when visitors divide their attention among exhibits.

Context

This sub‚Äëpattern is intended for gallery and museum spaces that:

  • Feature multiple points of interest dispersed across a nontrivial floor plan

  • Support real‚Äëtime user localization accurate enough to anchor and animate a virtual figure in situ

  • Seek to provide a more personable, dramaturgical escort experience than abstract wayfinding cues allow

Use When

  • Visitors prefer to ‚Äúfollow‚Äù a guide rather than decode symbolic markers

  • Maintaining a natural, steady walking pace is important for visitor comfort

  • The venue desires to embody thematic or narrative elements (e.g., a curator avatar or historical persona) in its navigation system

  • The system must adjust pacing dynamically without requiring manual speed controls

Solution

Avatar Instantiation & Path Binding

  • Spawn a 3D avatar at the user‚Äôs position and bind its movement to the authored path.

  • Monitor the visitor‚Äôs heading and speed; continuously adjust the guide‚Äôs velocity to remain at an optimal following distance (approx. 2‚Äì3‚ÄØm).

Kinematic Plausibility

  • Employ inverse‚Äëkinematics and subtle idle animations to maintain realism when the user pauses or veers off-course.

  • Colour‚Äëcode the avatar‚Äôs outline or attire to reflect navigation states (e.g., green for ‚Äúen route,‚Äù amber for ‚Äúpaused‚Äù).

Point‚Äëof‚ÄëInterest Menu

  • Provide a floating radial or list menu allowing users to select their next destination.

  • Display estimated travel time based on the avatar‚Äôs adaptive speed profile.

Gesture‚ÄëActivated Controls

  • Recognize a simple hand gesture (e.g., palm‚Äëup) to reveal a mini hand‚Äëmenu with Start, Pause, Resume, and End options.

  • Deliver haptic or auditory confirmation upon each command.

Auditory & Spatial Prompts

  • Issue spatialized vocal cues (e.g., ‚ÄúTurn left ahead‚Äù) and footstep sounds at key decision points.

  • Dynamically adjust volume and cadence in response to ambient noise and proximity.

Arrival Interaction

  • Upon reaching a PoI, have the avatar stop, turn toward the visitor, and perform a brief welcoming gesture.

  • Simultaneously trigger an on‚Äëscreen tooltip and a gentle chime to affirm arrival.

Notes

By anthropomorphizing wayfinding, the Avatar Guide reduces cognitive load and fosters social presence. Its adaptive pacing prevents visitor frustration caused by mismatched walking speeds, while gesture‚Äëactivated controls minimize visual clutter. The use of themed avatars can further reinforce the institution‚Äôs narrative identity.
